column4: All:  Have a sound problem.  About 12 installs attemps now.  Always fails.  What I think, after watching the installs go by several times, is that there are certain directories needed and the permission have to be right, and I think they either do not get created or the permissions are not correctly set.  I'm trying to learn where the install writes it's log, so I can see what write errors occur and try to correct these.
try: sudo atp-get install esound
Little misspell there, but corrected and watching the install.
had the same problem, that was my solution.
Hope it works for me!
Got msg "After unpacking 102kB of additional disk space will be used." but it did not install only downloaded.  What else is needed or do I re-init alsasound now?
Re-ran alsa-info.sh.  PB at: http://pastebin.ca/811119.  Restarted alsa-utils, which restarted alsa, but still no sound.  What next?
It never asked a Q
Let me try again!
Aha! Getting a "reading database thing now" did not do that before!
Also got the "Unpacking" and "Setting Up" message, so restarted when it finished.  But still no sound.
Try a reboot and see if that works,
Shutting down sometimes helps.

When I go to: <System> + <Preferences> + <Sound> and click to test get this error "audiotestsrc wave=sine freq=512 ! audioconvert ! audioresample ! gconfaudiosink: Could not open resource for writing.".  Also Speaker symbol still has the "/" for not active.
Shutting down sometimes helps. Try restarting.
The "alsa-info.sh" script errors looking for dir "/proc/asound" which it can not find.  Going to create that by hand and then try re-install.
Just restart.
When I do "mkdir /proc/asound" I get the error "mkdir: cannot create directory `/proc/asound': No such file or directory".  Wondering why?  Did "chmod 775 /proc" and no change.
If you aren't willing to follow instructions, don't ask.
Also have tons of numbered folders in "/proc".  Wonder if there is a directory number limit?
Just restart.
Just restart your computer and it will reconfig the sound with the new esound system, okay?
